particulars: Equipped (0001-0004) by the Compagnie van Verre of Amsterdam. Eerste Schipvaart under command of Kornelis de Houtman aboard the MAURITIUS. From 26-04 till 27-04 at Maio I.; from 04-08 till 11-08 in the Mosselbaai; from 13-09 till 07-10 in the Ampalazabaai; from 09-10 till 13-12 in S. Augustins Bay, where before departure 127 of the 249 men were still alive; 11-01 till 21-01 at Ste. Marie I.; from 23-01 till 12-02 in the Bay of Antongil. The AMSTERDAM was set on fire near Bawean, 11-01-1597.

Fleet (0005-0007) equipped by the Compagnie Ten Haeff of Middelburg under command of Gerard Le Roy aboard the ZON after the loss of the MAAN, which capsized while firing a salute near Dover. The fleet met the fleet of the Compagnie de Moucheron under command of Kornelis Houtman; 1 day at Maio I.; passing the Cape the 2 ships lost sight of each other.
De Cordes, on board of the HOOP, was killed by natives on La Mocha I., 11-11-1599 and succeeded by Hudcupee; the HOOP sailed via Hawaii and was lost with all hands, 24-09-1600.

Van Beuningen, vice-admiraal since 24-09-1598, aboard the LIEFDE was killed in S. Maria with 22 men and succeeded by Kwakernaak; the LIEFDE sailed via Hawaii and arrived in Japan 19-04-1600 with only 24/25 men. The Japanese confiscated the ship, but released the crew; later the ship was lost in Japanese waters.

Fleet (0024-0027) under command of admiraal Olivier van Noort aboard the MAURITIUS and vice-admiraal Jakob Klaasz. van Ilpendam aboard the HENDRIK FREDERIK. Total of those on board 248. The MAURITIUS and the EENDRACHT were equipped by a Rotterdam company, the HENDRIK FREDERIK and the HOOP by an Amsterdam company. From 11-12 till 17-12 at Principe I. 
From 02-06 till 21-06 at S. Clara I., where the EENDRACHT was deserted and set on fire, because of unseaworthiness; from 20-09 till 29-10 at Port Desire; October 9th. the HOOP was renamed EENDRACHT; from 04-11 till 29-02 in Strait of Magellan, where they meet the GELOOF of the fleet of Mahu; January 26th Van Ilpendam was left behind on an island because of insubordination, De Lint became his successor as vice-admiraal from 15-10 till 20-11 at the Philippines and December 9th. before Manila, where the EENDRACHT was captured by the Spaniards December 14th. The MAURITIUS proceeded alone to Borneo December 26th; the HENDRIK FREDERIK ran ashore near Ternate, February 1601 and was sold to the sultan of Ternate. Huidekoper, captain of the HOOP died October 7th and was succeeded by Pieter de Lint who on his turn was succeeded by Lambert Biesman January 28th, 1600, after his appointment as vice-admiraal in stead of Van Ilpendam.
Ran aground off Halmaheira, 1607.
18-08-1606 burnt in action before Malacca.
22-08-1606 burnt in action before Malacca. According to Commelin the master was Wouter Jakobsz.; according to Mac Leod Walter Karelsz. There were also 15 blacks on board.

Fleet (0107-0114) under adm. Paulus van Caerden aboard the BANDA and vice-adm. Adriaan Maartensz. aboard the WALCHEREN. The total number of those on board was 1060. From 23-05 till 03-06 on the roadstead of the isle of Wight, the 3 ships from Zeeland arrived here 25-05; 29-03 at Mocambique, where they started operations against the Portuguese. When leaving, 26-05, the ZIERIKZEE ran aground and was lost; the mainfleet was therefore unable to sail before June, 29th; from 08-06 till 17-07 at the Comoro I; from 04-08 till 26-08 again at Mozambique and 02-10 at Goa.
Riding at anchor off Ternate in 1608, the ship was lost due to bad weather (July 1608).
Riding at anchor off Ternate in 1608, the ship was lost due to bad weather.
Foundered 1607 Cabacella (Moz.).
The ship was forced by bad weather to take refuge in the harbour of Vlissingen, July 19th and was lost, making its way out July 20th.
Captured by the Spaniards off Manila, 25-04-1610.
Captured by the Spaniards off Manilla, 25-04-1610.
Captured and burnt by the Spaniards off Manilla 25-04-1610.
The ship was despatched to bring news of the forthcoming Twelve Years' Truce; stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near the Maledive Islands.
Captured by the Spaniards near Manila, 15-07-1610.
The BRAK lost sight of the fleet at 23-06; 03-08 at Mauritius. At 07-08-1613 the ship sailed aground near Macassar and was lost.
The CEYLON lost sight of the fleet 03-07.

Lost sight of the fleet; from 30-07 till 02-08 at the Bay of Antipara; 02-08 in the St.Lucia Bay, where it took over the remaining cargo of the MAURITIUS (5077); 21-08 departure from Madagascar via the Bay of Antongil; from 27-10 till 08-12 at Mauritius.
Lost sight of the fleet; from 24-07 till 03-08 in the 'Verhagens-baai'; from 29-08 till 27-09 at Mayotte.

Fleet (0143-0144) under the command of Hendrik Brouwer aboard the RODE LEEUW MET PIJLEN sailed the southern passage for the first time (latitude ca. 36° south), which was made obligatory in 1616. The GOUDA was captured by the Spaniards near Tidore, 04-05-1612.
The LEEUW was, because of its unseaworthiness, abandoned by its crew and set on fire, August 1615.
Ran aground near Surat and lost, 17-07-1617.
Coming from Manila lost near Japan, 31-01-1613.
Lost sight of the mainfleet after a heavy storm 05-07 but joined the fleet again at 22-10; in the meanwhile took on provisions in the Bay of Antongil.
Lost in the Indies 02-10-1614.
Stayed in the Indies and was, coming from Coromandel, foundered on the rocks of Engano I. 25-08-1616.

Fleet (0169-0170) under the command of Jasper van Surk aboard the MIDDELBURG. May 4th at Maio I.; August 10th the ZEELANDIA disappeared from sight and the MIDDELBURG reprovisioned in St. Lucia Bay. Later the MIDDELBURG was lost near Surat, 19-07-1617.
According to Coolhaas the ship arrived at Bantam 16-01-1615. The ship stayed in the Indies and ran aground in the river Andragiri 19-09-1615.
From April 1615 till May 1615 at Mauritius to collect the cargo of the wrecked GELDERLAND (6007).

Fleet (0183-0188) under Joris van Spilbergen aboard the GROTE ZON.The total number of those on board was 700-750. From 02-09 till 16-09-1614 off the Isle of Wight; from 23-12 till 14-01-1615 Ilha Grande; from 18-01 till 04-02 at S. Vincente; March 21st, mutiny aboard the MEEUWTJE. Fearing the navigation through the Strait of Magellan, the crew returned under command of Gerard Hermansz. van Rotterdam to La Rochelle, where the ship was sold. From 02-04 till 0-05 sailing through the Strait of Magellan. From 29-05 till 01-06, capture of S. Maria; July 17th, sea battle of Canate against 8 Spanish ships (2 Spanish ships were sunk); from 08-08 till 21-08, capture of Payta; 11-10 till 18-10 at Acapulco; 24-01 till 27-01-1616 at the Ladrones; 28-02 till 10-03 at Manila Bay. The GROTE ZON was lost in the battle of Manila, 16-04-1617.
Burnt in the battle of Manila 16-04-1617.
Captured by the English near Bantam, 15-12-1618.
From 21-02 till 04-03 Maio Island; from 27-03 till 11-06 at Cabo de Lopez Gonsalvez; from 18-06 till 29-06 at Annabon. Burnt at Batavia 24-03-1627.
Stayed in the Indies and was wrecked on the shore of China, September 1622.
Captured a Portuguese jacht, renamed the KLEIN AMSTERDAM. The ship stayed in the Indies and was laid up between 31-10-1627 and 31-10-1628.
Stayed in the Indies; wrecked on the African coast 21-06-1622.
Captured a Portuguese jacht, renamed it NASSAU.
Reprovisioned at Fogo Island, at 5,5ø South and 80 miles west of Sumatra the ship caught fire and was blown up; on 14-12-1619 the sloop of the HOORN arrived with the survivors at Bantam.

From 07-01 till 26-01 at Plymouth, where 3 man deserted; from 25-02 till 02-03 at Bravo Island; from 03-07 till 17-07 near St. Maria (Madagascar). The ship stayed in the Indies and was wrecked on the Westcoast of Sumatra. Also mentioned as NIEUW ZEELAND.
From 14-08 till 21-08 at Cape Lopez. The ship stayed in the Indies and was wrecked on the west coast of Ambon, 13-05-1622.

From 02-10 till 11-10 at Cape Lopez; February 5th with the GOUDEN LEEUW to the 'Dasseneiland' and St. Helena; from 15-02 till 25-02 at St. Helena. The ship stayed in the Indies and was lost near Sucatara; crew and cargo were saved.
Lost on a return voyage from Siam or Japan, 1627.
Stayed in the Indies and wrecked in the river Andragiry, September 1622.
Stayed in the Indies and lost between Amboina and Batavia, 1621.

Departure from Plymouth 31-01-1621; from 10-03 till 24-03 at S. Vincente. The ship stayed in the Indies and was lost, according to Mac Leod, near China according to K.A. 1007 near Batavia, 20-05-1628.
Departure from Plymouth 31-01-1621; from 10-03 till 24-03 at S. Vincente. The ship stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near Formosa, 19-07-1623.
Stayed in the Indies; captured by the Chinese I Kwan in 1627, but returned in 1628 and laid up in 1629.

After its departure March 1624 forced by adverse winds and leakage to return to Surat, where the cargo was brought aboard the SCHOONHOVEN. The VREDE stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near Hirado, September 1631.
Stayed in the Indies and lost north of Formosa, 1630.
Stayed in the Indies and lost in Japan, 1634.
Wrecked near Boa Vista, 1623. Its destination was Surat.
Pieter Kornelsz. Hartloop succeeded, on September 9th 1624, Meindert Egbertsz., who died 28-08-1624, as master of the AREND. The AREND was sold to the V.O.C. and lost near Cape Mauritius.
Pieter Kornelisz. Hartloop who became master of the AREND was succeeded by Pieter Hendriksz. The ship stayed in the Indies, under commission of the V.O.C. and was lost near the Moluccas.

Also mentioned as WINDHOND, according to Voorbeijtel Cannenburg. Salomon Willemsz. became master of the Hoop, 01-09 1623. June 1623 the ship was sent back to Holland, escorting 25 captured Spanish ships.
Stayed in the Indies and was lost on 'Boompjes-eiland', 17-02-1630.
Wrecked on the roadstead of Texel, 05-07-1625.
Wrecked on the coast of Portugal, 22-01-1626; 198 men were taken prisoner in Lisbon.
Stayed in the Indies and wrecked on the coast of China, 22-09-1631.
Stayed in the Indies and lost near Amoy, 12-10-1627, fighting the Portuguese.
Lost in the river Chincheu on the coast of China; 07-10-1633; according to Mac Leod lost near Amoy, 05-02-1629.
Reprovisioned in Sierra Leone, June 17th. The ship stayed in the Indies and was burnt in the river Chincheu.
Stayed in the Indies; ran aground and was destroyed by fire on the coast of Formosa, 28-06-1633. According to Mac Leod 08-11-1633.
Achterom and via Maio Isl. Stayed in the Indies and was lost near Mauritius, 1630.
Achterom and via Maio Isl. Stayed in the Indies and was broken up, 1631; according to Mac Leod lost, 1635.
Wrecked on the Needles of Wight, 23-10-1627.
Wrecked on the Needles of Wight, 23-10-1627. Wreck discovered.
From November 1627 till 07-01-1628 at Maio Island; blown up near Negapatnam fighting the enemy, 14-04-1630.
From November 1627 till 07-01-1628 at Maio Island; blown up, fighting the Portuguese near Malacca, 02-06-1636.
Stayed in the Indies and lost on 'Boompjes-eiland', February 1633.
Blown up off Sierra Leone, 18-10-1628.
Wrecked on the Wallabi Group, 04-06-1629. Wreck has been discovered (see H. Edwards).
From 28-01 till 17-02-1629 in the Downs; wrecked at St. Antao, 24-03-1629.
Blown up near Djambi, fighting the Portuguese, 05-04-1630. From 28-01 till 17-02 in the Downs; from 22-03 till 17-02 on the Cape Verde I.
Blown up near Djambi, fighting the Portuguese, 06-05-1630. According to Mac Leod 07-05-1629.
Stayed in the Indies and wrecked on an unknown reef near Borneo, 1634.
Sailed to the equator but returned because of bad trimming and was captured by a Dunkirk privateer.
Stayed in the Indies and was wrecked in the Bay of Tarpia, 07-10-1633.
Captured a Portuguese jacht during the voyage; wrecked on the coast of Cochin China, 1635.
Stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near the river Patrapa, 19-02-1637.
Stayed in the Indies; ran ashore in Strait Doeriam, May 1641 and was burnt.
Captured by a Dunkirk privateer.
No ports of call; stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near the 'Duizend eilanden'.
Reprovisioned at S. Vincente and stayed in the Indies; wrecked near the Pescadores 26-02-1637; according to Mac Leod surprised by the sultan of Martapoera and burnt, 1637.
Stayed in the Indies and was burnt by the Portuguese off Goa, 04-01-1638.
Stayed in the Indies and wrecked on a reef between Colombo and Negombo, 01-01-1640.
Stayed in the Indies and was set on fire by the Portuguese off Goa, 04-01-1638.
From 22-01 till 16-02-1636 in the Wielingen; coming from Banda the OTTER was wrecked upon a reef south of Buton, 1643; according to Coolhaas the crew was murdered 07-09-1643.
No ports of call; stayed in the Indies and was wrecked, 1650.
Via Sierra Leone, reprovisioning there for 8 days, leaving 19-07-1636; stayed in the Indies and was wrecked near Pulicat, 13-10-1638.
Sailed on the shallows off Brouwershaven and was wrecked; crew and cargo were saved.
0494-0509 (except 0508) departed with 2306 men; death-rate 263 (Coolhaas I, 730). Stayed in the Indies and was lost in action against the Spaniards near the Philippines.
Stayed in the Indies and was foundered on the rocks, east of Banka, June 1647.
14 men killed at the Cape; the ship stayed in the Indies and was lost in the Pescadores, 31-12-1639.
From 25-05 till 31-05 at S. Vicente, via Mauritius; the ship stayed in the Indies and was lost off Amboina, 15-02-1645.
Lost in action against the Portuguese off Malacca, 18-01-1642.
Also mentioned as VLIEGENDE HERT; stayed in the Indies and was wrecked in the Pescadores, 1643.
Wrecked on a reef off Goa, fighting the Portuguese and was lost, 06-12-1639.
Wrecked on the S.E. coast of Madagascar, 29-08-1639.
Wrecked off Sierra Leone, June or July 14th; crew and cargo were saved.
Wrecked in a storm when ready to leave Texel, 05-01-1640.
Stayed in the Indies and was wrecked in the river Ganges, 10-08-1648.
Stayed in the Indies, captured by Japanese and Cambodians in 1643, restored by them to the Dutch and broken up in Batavia, 1647.
From 12-02 till 26-02 at Mauritius; the ship stayed in the Indies and was lost south of the Isle of Champello.
Stayed in the Indies and was lost south of the Isle of Champello, 26-11-1641.
Stayed in the Indies; was wrecked on a reef south of Celebes, 04-03-1650.
Via Pernambuco; the ship stayed in the Indies, was wrecked on the roadstead of Batavia and broken up, January 1657.
Because of a storm forced to sail nae Brasil, which explains the long duration of the voyage; the ship stayed in the Indies and was lost off Negombo, 1651.

According to Aanw. 1891/19e departure 07-03-1642; returned to Texel and sailed again 30-09-1642. Then, having lost its masts back to Texel in October, sailing again 02-11-1642. The ship stayed in the Indies and was burnt in Bengal, 09-10-1650.
See number 0581 for the crew. The MAASTRICHT stayed in the Indies and was lost, sailing from Malabar to Batavia.
Stayed in the Indies and was lost in a sea battle in the Bay of Tigaol, 01-08-1646.
Stayed in the Indies and was broken up in Ternate, 1646. According to Uitloopboek, 4389, wrecked on a reef in Strait Banka. According to Schoute 35 men had died at arrival.
Wrecked near Majoe, 1653.
Stayed in the Indies and was lost in a sea battle in the Bay of Tigaol, 01-08-1646.
Wrecked on a reef in the Pescadores 27-10-1644; crew, except 1 man, and cargo saved.
Lost east of Batavia, 1653.
Wrecked on a reef leaving the Cape, 07-02-1644. The crew sailed to Batavia on board of the TIJGER and the VREDE.
Wrecked on the coast of Coromandel, 21-12-1653.
Via S. Tiago. Stayed in the Indies and was burnt off Bassaora, 05-01-1646.
Wrecked on a reef near Celebes, 04-03-1650.
Via S. Tiago; wrecked on a reef south of Celebes, 04-03-1659.
Stayed in the Indies and was blown up, January 20th, 1658, on Maginado by the Spaniards or by the crew.
Stayed in the Indies and was wrecked off Wangkang, 21-10-1647.
Stayed in the Indies; ran ashore on the Isle of Sapudi and was set on fire by the crew, 12-09-1646.
For the total number of those on board at the arrival in Batavia see the JONGE PRINS (0668). The ship was lost near Nusa Untelue, coming from Solor, 19-07-1656.
For the total number of those on board at the arrival in Batavia see the JONGE PRINS (0668). The ship was lost on the coast of China, 20-07-1652.
For the total number of those on board at the arrival in Batavia see the JONGE PRINS (0668). The ship was lost between Coromandel and Ceylon. The crew was saved.
For the total number of those on board at the arrival in Batavia see the JONGE PRINS (0668). The ship stayed in the Indies and was in use at Onrust; sunk 16-11-1663.
0682-0693 arrived with 2273 men, amongst whom 701 soldiers; death- toll 352 (Coolhaas II, 332). The ship stayed in the Indies and was wrecked on the coast of China in 1650.
Via Sierra Leone. The ship stayed in the Indies and was lost sailing from Taiwan to Japan, 16-08-1653.
Wrecked in the 'Sluise Gat', when leaving the Wielingen.
Via S. Tiago. The ship stayed in the Indies and was lost near the Arabian coast, 11-10-1653.
See the BREDA (0703) for the total number of those on board. The TROUW stayed in the Indies and was wrecked in a storm on the coast of Hitoe, 1659.
See the BREDA (0703) for the total number of those on board. The POTVIS stayed in the Indies and was wrecked on the coast of China, 1650.
Via Sierca Leone: the ship stayed in the Indies and was wrecked on a reef south of Celebes, 04-03-1650.
Via Tenerife. For the total number of those on board see the VREDE (0710). The ship was wrecked sailing from Batavia to Taiwan, June 1653.
Wrecked in a gale outside the Persian Gulf, 08-10-1653. No survivors, cargo (fl 284,824) was lost.
Wrecked near Taiwan, 09-08-1654. Crew and cargo were saved. Mentioned by the Uitloopboek 4389 as TAGORAS and by Coolhaas as TAYONAN.
Via S. Vincente. The ship stayed in the Indies and was lost off Arsapour, 19-10-1654; 51 deaths.
Wrecked on the Vlaamse banken, 06-05-1651.
Lost near Amboina (Novo Tello) 13-07-1654.
Blown up by its own powder off Pulicat, 19-10-1654.
No ports of call. The ship was lost near Taiwan with all hands, October 3rd, 1652.
Wrecked on the reefs of the Vuile Eiland in the Pescadores, 26-09-1655.

Via Brazil. After departure from the Cape command the ship under of Gerrit Abelsen went first to Gamron, then to Surat. Departure from Surat 11-11-1653. The ship was wrecked on the river of Cambodia (1-1-1657).
Via Sierra Leone (01-01-1653). On 22-04-1661 wrecked on the reefs of the island Roti near Timor.
After departure from Texel the ship went to Goeree. Departure from there 09-12-1652. The ship was wrecked on the island Schouwen, crew and cargo were saved and the ship was left 21-12.

After departure from Texel to Goeree. From there 09-12 back to Texel because of a lost rudder. Departure from Texel 09-02-1653. The ship was wrecked near the Shetland Islands on 02-03 (reefs of Bluemull Sound; 26 survivors; wreck recently discovered).
First call at Goeree till 01-12-1653 and from 08-12-1652 till 15-12-1652 again at Goeree because of adverse winds. Ship was wrecked near Batavia 30-05-1658 (Boompjes Islands).
Equipped for the Dutch war fleet and taken by the English 01-03-1653.
At Pipely (Balasore) wrecked in a heavy storm 22-10-1662; crew saved.
On 28-10-1654 wrecked on a reef at Taiwan's north coast.
After the Cape Elbert Kornelisz. Kes became master. On 28-10-1654 wrecked on a reef at Taiwan's north coast.
Stayed at the Cape for service; lost off Madagascar 02-12-1656.
Riding at anchor off Texel it was wrecked during a storm, but the cargo was saved.
On 24-04-1654 taken by the English at Dogger Bank.
On 15-04-1654 it captured a small English ship named MERCHANT at S. Vincente. The GOUDSBLOEM left S. Vincente 20-04. Broken up in 1665 in Bengal.
Via S. Tiago. Lost at Tanete (north of Macassar), March 1660.
Via Torbay. Wrecked with all hands lost during a voyage from Batavia to Japan in 1659/1660.
In April 1661 sunk at Pegu, 10 men were drowned.
On 12-11-1665 taken by the Portuguese in the Bay of Colombo.
From 21-12-1654 till 21-03-1655 back in Goeree. On 24-12-1664 wrecked near Macassar.
On 16-09-1661 blown up in a battle against the Chinese off Formosa.
On 28-04-1656 wrecked at the west coast of Australia. Value of the cargo: fl. 185,000.
On 11-09-1656 wrecked at the roads of Taiwan in a hurricane.
Because of adverse winds for 4 weeks at Wight. On 28/29-09-1661 run aground and wrecked on the south shore of the Andaman Islands.
Via England. Wrecked in the Bay of Gale, 15-05-1663.
On 21-05-1661 wrecked in the Bay of Gale.
In October 1661 wrecked in the Bay of Bengal.
From 18-04 till 17-05-1656 at Wight. On 11-11-1659 wrecked at Palembang.
For 10 days at the Shetland I. In 1663 wrecked at the island Damman(?).
On 17-08-1661 wrecked in a battle against the Chinese.
Via St. Helena. In March 1658 wrecked on a reef at Ceylon, crew and cargo were mainly saved.
Remained for service at the Cape, and probably sailed to Batavia later on. Sailing to Arakan in 1665/66 it was wrecked.
A Portuguese slave ship carrying 250 slaves was captured off Brazil. At the arrival at the Cape about 80 of them had died and many were ill; some 100 slaves arrived at Batavia.
Sailing to Canton in 1659, the GEELMUIDEN was wrecked.
According to Daghregister, 1659, 32, the ship arrived at Batavia with 81 seafarers, 39 soldiers, and 5 passengers. It was wrecked on 25-06-1660 (off Taiwan?)

According to KA 1119 the ship departed from the Vlie on 22-10-1658, according to KA 3971 the date of departure was 22-11-1658. Via Australia. During a battle against the Chinese the ship was wrecked, probably in 1661.
Via Canary Islands. Via Mauritius to accompany the PAREL which made water (see 0897). Attempting to relieve Fort Zeelandia at Formosa the KORTENHOEF was wrecked, 16-09-1661.

captain: Delfshaven, Lukas Bouwersz. van der Lek van
particulars: Via Mauritius to accompany the PAREL which made water (see 0897). Wrecked in a battle against the Chinese in 1661.
Returning from Nagasaki to Batavia in 1663, the ship was wrecked.
Via Maio Island. Sunk off Macassar in 1668.
The two 'passengers' who embarked at the Cape were prisoners; one of them died. Wrecked on a reef at Salayar, 07-01-1663.
Via S. Vincente. Remained for service for about one year at the Cape before leaving for Ceylon with 45 men. The ship was wrecked off Bimelepatnam, 09-11-1665.
At the Cape 58 French survivors of the wrecked MARECHAL embarked; three of them died.
At the Cape 58 French survivors of the wrecked MARECHAL embarked.
Via Torbay where one seaman deserted. One child was born during the voyage. The ship was wrecked off Mishima Islands, 26-08-1663.
At the arrival at Batavia the crew included 10 stowaways from the return fleet (see 5482), who had come on board at the Cape. On 22-02-1663 wrecked off the coast of China; crew was saved.
On 15-06-1661 for the second time from the Vlie. Via Cape Verde (12 till 22-08) and Saldanha Bay (06-12-1661 till 10-01-1662). Wrecked off Ceram, 09-02-1665.
The ship was wrecked near Japan (Mishima Islands) on 26-08-1663.
This ship was also destined for the attack on Mozambique, but fell behind and left the fleet on 29-06-1662 at 5° N. Stayed at the Cape. Wrecked at Amboina in 1672.
The ship lost its bowsprit, foremast and several topmasts. See also KENNEMERLAND (0968).
See KENNEMERLAND (0968). On board: Vice-admiraal Willem Volgers. The ship was wrecked on a voyage to China on 16-09-1663.
Wrecked at Cape Verde in June 1662.
Via Goeree, departure on 09-10-1662. The ship was wrecked between Bima and Macassar on 1/2-10-1670.
The 'passengers' who embarked at the Cape, were Portuguese prisoners. The ship was wrecked on a voyage between Bengal and Batavia on 18-11-1670.
The 'passengers' who embarked at the Cape, were 4 Portuguese prisoners. The ship was wrecked on 09-11-1665 off Bimelepatnam.

At the Cape Meindert Roelofsz. became master on the MEES; master on the HOOGKARSPEL after the Cape was Andries Brant. One seafarer was thrown overboard because of 'sodomy'. The 'passengers' who embarked at the Cape were Portuguese prisoners. The ship was wrecked between Tonkin and Japan in 1670.
Wrecked on the rocks of the 'Hytanse' Islands on 17-12-1667; 33 men were drowned; there were about 13 survivors.
Wrecked at Macassar because of an explosion in the gunpowderroom, on 09-08-1668.
Wrecked at Bengal, 16-04-1673.
Taken by 4 English privateers near Wingurla on 02-11-1672.
Burnt in Japan, off Decima on 07-07-1665.
Taken by the English.
From 06-01 till 01-07-1665 at Goeree. The ship was burned at Batavia after an explosion in the gunpowderroom on 05-05-1666.
Wrecked on Stour a Stack in the Outer Skerries, Shetland I. on 20-12-1664. All hands lost, also the cargo of fl.120,000.
New departure from the Wielingen: 24-03-1665. Via Annabon and Cape Lopez, where 7 seafarers and 9 soldiers deserted. Wrecked on a voyage to Japan in 1669.
Wrecked at one of the Tiger Islands in 1674.
The ship was wrecked at the Orissa coast on 03-11-1670.
Via S. Tiago. One soldier was drowned. According to Daghreg. 1675 and K.A. 1196 laid up and sold at Batavia in 1675; according to Coolhaas III the ship was wrecked coming from Bengal in 1671.
The ship was wrecked west of the Shetland Islands.
Via Maio I. (25-06-1666). The ship stayed near Lombok from 26-02 till 10-03-1667. The OOIEVAAR was wrecked in the Ganges in Bengal, 30-07-1668.

Acc. to K.A. 3979 the ship left the Wielingen on 31-06-1666. The ship returned to the Maas on 30-07 and set out again on 01-08. Via S. Vincente: two seafarers deserted. The ship was wrecked near Banda, 28-06-1670.
The ship was wrecked on 02-05-1669, when sailing from the Bay of Swally; the cargo was partly saved.

3 soldiers became seafarers. Acc. to K.A.1158 Hendrik Boudewijnse was master. At S. Vincente on 28-12-1666 till 25-01-1667. Coming from Persia the ship was wrecked at Baios de Padua on 05-07-1668, with 27 men drowned.
Taken by the English near Ireland in June 1667.

The master died near the Abrolhos, and was succeeded by Kornelis Mathall. At Bravo I. there was a mutiny of some soldiers. Four soldiers were thrown overboard, one seaman and five soldiers went to the MEERMAN (1068). One child was born. The ship was wrecked near the isle of Galle (Bengal) on 08-08-1671.
The ship was burnt and wrecked at Poulo Timaon on 07-06-1670.
The ship was wrecked near Macassar on 04-08-1668.
The ship was wrecked at the coast of Africa about 9 miles north of the Cape on 31-05-1668. Two men were drowned; one of them was the master.
Captured at the Cape by part of its own crew, 23-06-1669; the ship sailed to Pernambuco and was taken by the Portuguese.
The ship lost its masts in a storm at 17° C. and 107° E.
The ship was wrecked east of Cape 'Hangklip', at the East African coast on 20-02-1673.
Via Duins (till 04-01-1669). The ship was wrecked in the Ganges on 20-09-1672; the cargo of fl. 204,000 was mainly lost.
Wrecked at Tuticorin on 29-04-1670.
The ship was wrecked at the Damar Islands on 24-01-1683.
The ship was wrecked in Banka Strait on 04-06-1671.
The ship was met in the Channel by two Turkish privateers, but escaped. Via S. Tiago. The ship was wrecked at Tuticorin on 22-02-1682.
The ship was wrecked on the Goodwin Sands on 26-11-1670.
The ship was wrecked in the river Ganges on 05-12-1674.
Via Falmouth. The ship was wrecked at the island Fortuin near Sumatra in November 1677.
The ship was wrecked in a storm off Formosa on 02-08-1672.
Acc. to Daghregister 1672 the ship left the Cape on 29-02-1672. In 1674 the ship was wrecked off S.Tomé.
The ship was taken by the English.
The ship was wrecked off Colombo on 15-12-1677.
Taken by the English on 10-10-1672.
The ship was wrecked off S. Tomé in 1674.
The master died on 30-01-1673; he was succeeded by Willem van der Hop. The ship left the Cape on 21-04-1673, acc. to Daghregister 1673. It was wrecked 50 miles east of the Cape on 23-08-1673.
The ship was taken by the English, retaken by a Zeeland privateer, and restored in Zeeland. It finally left the Wielingen on 26-05-1673. Laid up at Ceylon in 1690.
Lost near England in February 1673.
The ship was blown up at the roadstead of Batavia in 1690.
Second departure on 22-06-1674. The ship was wrecked on a reef near the 'Thousand Islands', on 13-09-1684.
The ship took refuge at the Shetland Islands in December 1673, where it was taken by the English in February 1674.

Via Plymouth (15 days), where 10 seafarers and 5 soldiers deserted. Via S. Tiago. Acc. to K.A. 1202 the ship arrived at the Cape on 12-05-1675. The ship was wrecked near the Thousand Islands' during a voyage to Palembang (01-09-1684).

Via Plymouth where 7 seafarers deserted on 13-02-1675. The master died during the voyage and was buried at S. Tiago. He was succeeded by Laurens Verbeek. The ship was wrecked at Coromandel in January 1680.
Via S. Vincente. The ship ran ashore and was wrecked at Colombo on 05-01-1680.
Acc. to Daghreg. 1676 the ship departed from Texel on 12-05-1675. The ship was wrecked in the Ganges in Bengal on 23-05-1679.
Via Duins (16 till 17-01-1676). The ship ran ashore and was wrecked at Alkmaar Island near Batavia on 11-02-1686.
The ship was wrecked at the Cape Verde Islands.
Via Duins (16 till 17-01-1676). Via S. Tiago. The ship was burned on 29-01-1677 and the wreck was sold at Batavia on 26-02-1677.

Because of icing the ship took refuge in the Wielingen; second departure on 11-03-1677. Via S. Tiago. Acc. to Daghreg. 1677 at the Cape on 30-06-1677. Burned in the Bay of Gale on 19-12-1679 (6 to 8 casualties).
Original departure from Texel: 07-12-1677. One soldier was lost during the voyage.

Via Fernando de Noronha (02-06-1678), Madagascar (114 slaves bought for the west coast of Sumatra; 51 died), Mauritius, Magalage and the west coast of Sumatra. The ship was laid up or wrecked in 1685.
The ship was wrecked in the South Atlantic.
Via S. Tiago. During the voyage 4 seafarers were lost. Unknown number of passengers on board.
One seaman was lost during the voyage. Laid up and sold at Batavia in April 1687.
Via S. Tiago, where 4 seafarers deserted. Wrecked on a reef (off Ternate?) on 22-05-1682.
Acc. to Daghreg. 1680 the ship departed from Veere. Via Plymouth (21 till 31-03-1680) and S. Tiago (27-04-1680), where respectively one and two soldiers deserted. Wrecked at Arrakan on 20-10-1681.
Wrecked between the Cape and India on 36° S. in August 1680. All hands lost.
Via Cape Lopez Gonsalvez. The ship was wrecked on the Ganges in Bengal in 1688.
Via S. Tiago (arrival 25-04-1682). Acc. To Daghreg. 1682 the ship arrived at the Cape on 06-08-1682. The ship was wrecked west of Sumatra in 1684.
The ship was wrecked.
Via S. Tiago (arrival on 22-08 and Annabon, arrival on 20-10-1684). According to K.A. 1297 the ship departed from the Cape on 20-02-1685. The ship was taken by the French at Ceylon in 1690.
Via S. Tiago (23-08 till 28-08-1684). According to K.A. 1297 the ship arrived on 20-10-1684 at the Cape and departed on 10-12-1684. Wrecked in the mouth of the Ganges in January 1686.
Via the west coast of Sumatra (06-07 till 22-07-1685). Wrecked in Sunda Strait in 1697; according to Daghregister 1697 laid up at Batavia in 1697.
The ship was wrecked in Banka street on a voyage to Siam on 18-09-1686.
The ship was wrecked on the Sorlings. All hands were lost.
Via England where 2 seafarers deserted. Wrecked on the roads of Semarang because of leakage on 21-08-1697.
Wrecked at Temate in 1689. According to Daghregister 1696 sold at Batavia, July 1696.
Via S. Tiago. The ship stayed at the Cape. On 16-01-1690 wrecked at Klippenpunt about 15 miles west of Cape St. Francis.
Wrecked at Ponte Pedro in 1691.
Wrecked at the river Ganges in 1690.
Taken by the French in the English Channel on 28-10-1688, but the ship was returned and then renamed HENNETJE (1722).
Taken by the French in the English Channel.
On 29-11-1688 the ship was wrecked at Hanglip (Shetland Islands).
The ship was wrecked at the roads of Batavia in 1698.
Via S. Tiago (16-07 till 23-07-1691). The ship was wrecked at Macassar on 29-03-1697.
The ship was wrecked on the roads of Surat on 07-05-1697.
The ship was taken by the French off the Scottish coast and was burned.

Shortly after departure the master Wijnand Bouwman changed place with Kornelis Mesdag, master on the VOSMAAR (1650). Via S. Tiago (16-10 till 28-10-1692) where 5 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted. January or February 1699 wrecked at Ligoor (Siam).
Wrecked west of Robben Island in December 1693.
The ship was wrecked at St. Helena Bay in December 1693.
The ship ran aground between Batavia and the Cape in March 1697, due to the loss of the main mast.

According to Coolhaas VI, (index, p. 977) this ship was called SPAARNE. The ship was forced by mutiny to cast anchor from 04-05 till 20-05-1694 off the island of Tercera (the Canaries). Here 4 seafarers and 1 soldier were left behind. 2 soldiers and 2 seafarers proved to be absent at departure. Lost on the 4th of November 1698 coming from Japan.
The ship was wrecked at the Cape on 24-05-1697.
Wrecked west of the isle of Pinancro on 21-03-1704.
The ship was wrecked at Surat on 20-09-1700. According to Coolhaas VI, 17, this ship arrived on 01-09-1698 in Batavia with a letter dated 15 December 1697.
Between the Cape and Batavia taken by the French in February 1697.
The ship was wrecked at the Flemish coast on 22 or 23-07-1696.
From 22-07 till 24-07-1697 at Cape Capus; the master Willem de Haze died. Second departure from the Cape on 23-12-1697. Wrecked on the sands of the river Palembang in 1703.
The ship was wrecked three miles off the Cape on 27-05-1698.
From 25-02 till 04-03-1700 at Duins. On 21/22-11-1702 sunk on the roads of Batavia.
The ship was wrecked at the Malacca coast (Cape Rochado) on 01-01-1702.
From 21-01 till 08-03-1701 at Wight; on 13-01-1705 at the coast of Coromandel taken by 4 French ships.
The ship lost the main mast on 24-11-1701 and took refuge at Milfort till 23-04-1702. 35 Seafarers and 11 soldiers ran away; 31 seafarers and 17 soldiers signed on.
The ship was wrecked on 03-04-1702 at Jutteneiland, Saldanha Bay; there were 99 survivors; the cargo was lost.
The master might also have been called Leroux (6100). On 14-01-1707 taken by the pirate 'Cangie Angrie'.
The ship was captured on 13-03-1703.
The ship was captured on 13-03-1703.
The ship was wrecked at Ameland on 13-12-1703.
In a storm main mast was damaged and the ship ran aground at Annabon, from 14-10 till 19-10-1704. From 12-11 till 19-11-1704 at St-Helena.
In a storm the ship lost the bowsprit, and took refuge at Annabon from 14-09 till 29-09-1704. From 12-11 till 19-11-1704 at St. Helena.
The ship departed for Japan on 30-06-1708 and was lost.
The ship was captured on 14-02-1705 by two pirates from St. Malo.
Taken by three French ships on 13-04-1706.
Taken by three French ships and burnt on 13-04-1706.
On 13-07-1706 taken by seven French ships.
Two of the passengers were stowaways. The ship was wrecked in Sunda Strait in April 1709.
The two passengers at departure were stowaways. The ship taken by pirates at the Smalle Baai in 1707.
The ship was taken by the French at Ceylon in 1709.
The ship was burnt in the Saldanha Bay on 28-05-1709.
Two of the passengers were stowaways. The ship was lost on a voyage to Bengal in 1709.

Together with the OUWERKERK (2042) held up at Texel till 24-01-1708. At Edinburgh from 29-01 till 25-03-1708 where 12 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted and 10 seafarers embarked. Taken by the French on a voyage to Surat on 18-09-1709.
Taken by the French on 03-06-1708, between the equator and the Cape.
The ship was taken by the French on 20-10-1708.
The ship was taken by the French on 28-10-1708.
The two passengers were stowaways. Lost at Grisee in 1719.
The two passengers were stowaways. At 'Hitland' from 18-10 till 23-10-1709. The ship was lost in Asia.
The three passengers were stowaways. Lost at Banda in 1711.
Lost after departure from Ceylon in 1710.
The ship was lost on the coast of Mozambique on 09-06-1711.
Among the passengers were four stowaways. Lost after departure from Macassar in November 1718.
At Goeree from 16-01 till 31-01-1711. Taken by the French man of war L'ARSELLE at Cape Finisterre on 21-02-1711.
The ship was taken by two French ships on 30-04-1711.
From 13-12-1711 till 04-01-1712 at S. Tomé. Via Annabon. Wrecked 40 miles north of the Murchinson river at the west coast of Australia. The wreck was discovered in 1927.
On 18-01-1712 the ship was taken by three French warships.
Lost at the reef Miouw of the Shetlands; only one man was saved.
Lost at the Shetlands.
Among the passengers were 2 stowaways. Lost in 1714 at the Paracelles on the way to Japan.
The ship was lost on a reef of the Shetlands on 15-03-1713.
Burnt off the coast of Ceylon on 15-11-1721.
On 03-10-1717 burnt at the Cape.
Wrecked on the river Ganges in 1718.
The ship was wrecked on a voyage to Japan on 04-08-1719.
The ship was lost on a voyage to Japan in 1719.
The ship was lost on a voyage to Japan on 14-08-1719.
The ship was taken by two pirates on 07-07-1718, but was apparently released.
Wrecked at the coast of Eijerland, on 04-01-1720.
On 09-02 back at Texel, second departure on 23-02-1720; after coming back again, third departure on 21-07-1720. Wrecked at the Cape on 15-06-1722.
Between 14-08 and 18-08-1722 lost near Japan.
On 19-04-1722 taken by 3 pirates at the Rio Delagoa.
1 Soldier became a seafarer. The ship was lost in 1725.
On 15-06-1722 wrecked at the Cape.
Lost at departure on 22-12-1721.
Wrecked at the Cape on 15-06-1722.
Lost at the Cape on 15-06-1722.
Lost at the Cape on 15-06-1722.
Lost at the Cape on 15-06-1722.
Lost on a voyage to Japan in 1724.
Wrecked near Japara in 1728.
On 07- 11-1723 wrecked on the coast of Africa, near the Olifants-river (3° 20' S.). 9 Men were saved.
The ship was lost between the Cape and Batavia.
On 14-02-1724 wrecked on the sands between Grevelingen and Dunkirk.
At S. Tiago from 02-07 till 14-07-1724. Danvers died during the voyage and was succeeded by Daniel Overbeek. Wrecked between Coromandel and Batavia in 1730.
At Duins from 28-10 till 01-11-1724. The ship was wrecked on the west coast of Sumatra on 25-02-1735.
The ship was wrecked at the island of Porto Santo on 19-11-1724.
Till 06-01 at Duins; from 30-01 till ?-02-1725 at Portsmouth. The ship was wrecked at the Saldanha Bay on 1/2-07-1736.
At Duins on 05-02-1725. Wrecked at the Cape on 21-05-1737.
Wrecked at the island of Rondoe, at the coast of Norway on 08-03-1725.
The ship was lost between the Cape and Batavia.
The ship was lost at one of the Maldive Islands on 08-05-1726. The cargo was saved.
The ship was wrecked near Plymouth on 09-10-1725.
At Plymouth from 09-10 till 21-10-1725. The ship was lost between Padang and Bengal in 1727.
The ship was wrecked in Asia in 1733.

At Duins from 13-11 till 23-11-1726. On 09-06-1727 the ship was wrecked on Gun Island in the southern part of the Houtman's Abrolhos. 82 Survivors reached Batavia on 30-04-1728 with the complete cargo. (See H. Edwards.)
Lost between Ternate and Bima in 1730.
On 21-05-1729 wrecked at the coast of Malabar.
Wrecked at the Wielingen on 17-11-1727.
From 17-11 till 23-11-1727 at Torbay. The was ship wrecked near Cape Agulhas on 08-01-1730.
Wrecked off the Cape on 03-07-1728.
Wrecked on 03-07-1728.
On 03-07-1728 wrecked off the Cape.
Wrecked on the reefs of Barra Island near Scotland in March 1728, Remains of the ship were located in March 1972.
Wrecked between Persia and Batavia in 1731.
At Duins from 14-05 till 15-05-1729. Two soldiers became seafarers. Wrecked on the river Ganges in 1730.
One soldier became a seafarer. Wrecked in Sunda Strait in 1731.
The ship was wrecked at the Noorderhaaks on 09-12-1729. Original destination was China.
Lost on its way to Japan in 1731.
First departure from Texel on 10-05-1730. The ship was taken by privateers and forced to stay at Algiers from 15-05 till 05-06-1730. Back at Texel on 13-08-1730. Laid up at Batavia on 22-04-1738.
First departure from Texel on 10-05-1730. The ship was taken by privateers and forced to stay at Algiers from 15-05 till 05-06-1730. Back at Texel on 13-08-1730.

Back at Texel from 28-05 till 24-06-1731. One seafarer ran away; one seafarer went to the HUIS TE MARQUETTE (2847). The ship stayed at the Saldanha Bay from 13-01 till 14-02-1732. Acc. to K.A. 2100 the master was Klaas Meelhoop; he probably succeeded Jan Molentijn during the voyage. The ship was wrecked on 01-06-1734.

At S. Tiago from 20-06 till 26-06-1732: 3 seafarers and 3 soldiers ran away; 25 seafarers, 22 soldiers and one passenger from the SLOT TER HOGE (2877) came aboard. The ship was wrecked at Gale on 23-10-1735.
Wrecked at Ilha de Mayo on 19-06-1732. Wreck discovered.
Wrecked at Rembang in 1737.
From 02-07 till 10-07-1733 at Guinea: 1 seafarer deserted. Wrecked at Bantam in September 1740.
At Duins from 09-07 till 12-07-1733. On 05-08-1733 wrecked at the Cape Verde Islands.
Wrecked near the Chinese coast on its outward bound voyage to China.
At Robben Island 21-02-1735. Wrecked on 10-03-1740 at the island of Watubela near Banda.
Wrecked at departure on 03-02-1735.
Wrecked at departure on 03-02-1735.
Jan de Jagerdied, Anthonie Uiterschouw became master. From 19 till 24-10 at Duins. The NIEUWVLIET replaced the ANNA CATHARINA (2977), wrecked in February 1735.
From 19 till 24-10 at Duins. The WESTKAPELLE replaced the 'T VLIEGEND HART (2978), wrecked in February 1735.

From 13 till 18-02-1736 the ship was back at Texel. On 19-02-1736 it stranded on Goodwin's Sand; 102 seafarers, 44 soldiers and 9 craftsmen deserted or died; the crew was completed with 111 seafarers and 28 soldiers; on the fifth of May 1736 the ship departed from Duins in a damaged condition.
On 13-02-1736 the HILLEGOM returned to Texel, but was wrecked there, one day after its initial departure.
From 13 till 18-02-1736 the ship was back at Texel. As the BUIS (3013) and the LOOSDRECHT (see 3019), the MEERMOND stranded on Goodwin's Sand, 19-02-1736.
According to KA 2288, the RIDDERKERK was wrecked in 1743 at Conati in Persia.
From 13-01 till 17-02-1738 the ship was at Portsmouth: 2 seafarers deserted. The passengers included 3 slaves (one male and two females). The STEENHOVEN was wrecked on a voyage to Bandain 1741.
One day after its departure from Texel the ROOSWIJK was wrecked at Goodwin's Sand on 09-01-1740.
The VIS was wrecked 'behind the Waterplaats' at the Cape on 06-05-1740.
The BETHLEHEM stranded at the Flemish sandbanks off Oostende on 29-12-1741. See also 3252. The ship was bound for Ceylon.
The PAPENBURG replaced the wrecked BETHLEHEM (see 3233). The ship was sold at Batavia on 05-05-1747.
During the voyage one seafarer became soldier. The HOFVLIET replaced the WATERVLIET, wrecked in May 1742 (see 3248).
The RUYVEN called at Duins from 28-06 till 01-07-1743. On 11-09-1745 the ship was wrecked on the Ganges.
From 20 till 29-08-1743 the HEUVEL was at S. Tiago. The ship replaced the ENKHUIZEN, lost in 1742 (see 7138).
The HOLLANDIA was wrecked at the Sortings on 13-07-1743. The wreck was found in 1971; coins from the HOLLANDIA were put up for auction in 1972.
The VERWACHTING was lost in 1744 on a voyage from China to Surat.
The LEEUWERIK called at S. Tiago (10 till 17-07-1744). In 1748 the ship was wrecked near Macassar.

Some of the 29 persons who disembarked at the Cape went to the KETEL (see 3304); the 16 embarking persons partially came from the KETEL and the LEIDEN (see 3321). One soldier became cook's wain. The BROUWER replaced the ABBEKERK, wrecked on a return voyage in 1742 (see 7139).

The NIEUWERKERK called at Duins from 10-10 till 14-11-1745 where 7 soldiers who had tried to desert were delivered to the DORDRECHT, a man-of-war; another soldier turned out to be a woman and was put on shore. The NIEUWERKERK was wrecked in 1748 on a voyage from Batavia to Banda. Francois Pennink and Reinier van der Luchten also are mentioned in sources as master of the NIEUWERKERK.

The PATMOS was at S. Tiago from 02 till 10-05-1746. It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. One source mentions Jan de Wever as master of the PATMOS. On 27-10-1752 the ship was wrecked at the reef 'na de Smalle Baei'.
From 03 till 13-02-1747 the NIEUW WALCHEREN called at Robben Island. The ship was wrecked on the roads of Surat on 24-05-1748.
The OUD BERKENRODE did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. On 04-12-1747 the ship was wrecked 'in the Bight of Anjer'; most of the cargo and crew was saved.
3386/- Is the seventh voyage of this ship, which during its first four voyages was called WAPEN VAN HOORN. The ship was wrecked on a return voyage from Surat to Batavia on 08-06-1751.
The VLISSINGEN was lost between patria and the Cape.
In 1748 the HUIS TE PERSIJN was wrecked on a return voyage from Japan.
On 25-10-1747 the REIGERSDAAL was wrecked off the Cape. Wreck discovered.

The SCHELLAG called at S. Tiago from 22-09 till 01-10-1747 where one sailmaker was taken over by the IMMAGOND A (see 3404), another seafarer and 16 soldiers deserted. In 1748, during a return voyage from Japan, the ship was captured by the French.

26-05-1748 Was the final date of departure of the BREDENHOF; on 06-05-1748 it set out for the first time, but the ship stranded 'at the Haaks' and returned to Texel on 10-05. The two passengers were stowaways found after the departure from the Cape; one of them was the wife of a sergeant.
One source mentions Thomas Hardy as master. The ZEELANDIA was wrecked in the Indies.
The SCHUILENBURG called at Duins from 09 till 15-1 1-1748. For seven years the ship was on service at the Cape; in 1756 it was wrecked on a voyage from the Cape to False Bay.

On 17-01-1749 the OVERSCHIE was driven out of its course by a heavy storm, the ship stranded near Portsmouth; before it got afloat 137 seafarers, 83 soldiers and 12 craftsmen deserted. From 17-02, the day the ship got afloat, till 10-05-1749 the OVERSCHIE remained at Portsmouth; the diminished crew was enlarged by 113 seafarers, 74 soldiers, 3 craftsmen and 12 passengers, all sent from Delft. During the voyage at least 5 soldiers probably became seafarers.

On 17-01-1749 a storm drove the PASGELD out of its course; the ship stranded near Portsmouth; after getting afloat it sailed to Spithead. The PASGELD remained there till 09-02 and, after a vain attempt to depart, from 12-02 till 10-04- 1749. The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay.
From 05 till 11-08-1749 the KRABBENDIJKE called at S. Tiago. The ship replaced the DIEMERMEER, wrecked in 1747 (see 7257).

Initially the RUST EN WERK sailed out on 28-10-1747, but the ship was driven out of its course and arrived at Surinam, 26-04-1748; it returned to Goeree on 27-04-1749. Some sources mention Markus Tetting as master; he probably succeeded Verschuur after the failure in 1747-'49. The 13 persons who disembarked at the Cape included some deserters. Taken by a 'Maccassaersen vrijman' called Frans Fransz.

The 84 soldiers who embarked at Texel included 7 gunners. The KLEVERSKERKE called at Duins (26 till 28-04) and at S. Tiago (from 22 till 27-05-1750). The ship did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. It also called at Bantam, where 59 soldiers disembarked. The 15 deceased military included 3 gunners, 4 gunners disembarked at Batavia. As appears from a resolution of gouverneur-generaal en raden the KLEVERSKERKE was wrecked during a voyage to Macassar in 1761.

After having lost its rudderon the Flemish Banks, 10-05, the OSDORP called at Duins (from 13-05 till 21-07-1750). This delay was due to a mutiny. 19 Mutineers were taken over by a man-of-war. The OSDORP also called at Bantam, where 52 soldiers disembarked.
The SCHAKENBOS did not call at the Cape, but at False Bay. During the voyage one soldier probably became a seafarer. On 17-02-1752 the SCHAKENBOS was wrecked in Manipa Strait.

On 12-07-1752 the OVERNES set out for the first time, but it ran aground and returned to Texel. The ship called at S. Tiago (27-02 till 07-03-1752). It did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. During the voyage a number of soldiers probably became seafarers.

The DRIE HEUVELEN called at Portsmouth from 09 till 21-10-1752. On 19-05-1753 the ship departed from the Cape; it arrived at Madagascar; on 17-12-1753 it returned to the Cape. In 1758 the DRIE HEUVELEN, sailing from Banda, was wrecked on a reef.
The OUWERKERK called at Plymouth from 09 till 21-10-1752, where 4 seafarers and 1 soldier deserted. In 1758 the ship was wrecked in the Indies.
The cargo of the BLOEMENDAAL consisted among other things of f 215,629 in cash. In 1756 the ship was wrecked off Surat.

The DIEMEN carried among other things f 103,542 in cash. 3577/- Is the third voyage of this ship, which during its previous two voyages was called KASTEEL VAN TILBURG (see 3468/7366). In 1756 it was wrecked in the Indies.
The BREDENHOF carried f 315, 000 in cash. Foundered 06-06-1753 on a reef off the coast of Mozambique; wreck discovered.
The cargo of the VOORZICHTIGHEID consisted among other things of f 60,005 in cash. On 08-06-1757 the VOORZICHTIGHEID, loaded with rice, ran aground at the Cape and was wrecked.
From 16 till 17-09-1753 the VOORBURG called at Duins, where one seaferer disembarked. In 1756 the ship was wrecked off Bengal.

On 08-10 the PRINSES CAROLINA set out for the first time, three days later it had to return to Texel. The ship called at S. Tiago from 19 till 24-11-1753. It carried f 42,700 in cash. The PRINSES CAROLINA replaced the AMSTELLAND, wrecked in September 1751 at the island Sylt (see 3530).
3620/- Is the fifth voyage of this ship, which during its four preceding voyages was called EENDRACHT (see 3523/7397). In 1756 the ship was wrecked at Ceylon.
In 1758 the OOSTKAPELLE was wrecked off the Coromandel Coast.
The STADWIJK called at Bantam on 04-07-1757, where 6 seafarers went ashore. During the voyage 10 soldiers probably became seafarers. In 1759 the ship got lost during a voyage to Japan.
On 08-08-1758 the HAARLEM was seized by the French off Pondichery in India; later on the ship was wrecked.
The passenger who went ashore at the Cape was an ex-soldier who had turned out to be a woman. In 1763 the HERCULES was wrecked on a voyage to Timor.
The ZEELELIE did not call at the Cape but at Simon's Bay. In 1764 the ship was wrecked during a voyage to Banda.
On 16-10-1758 the ERFPRINS ran aground near Calais and was wrecked. It was replaced by another ERFPRINS, previously called DELFT; in April 1759 the new ERFPRINS departed from Goeree (see 3757).

From 04 till 28-11-1758 the SCHOLTENBURG was at Portsmouth. On 07-05-1759, two months after its arrival at the Cape, the SCHOLTENBURG, accompanied by the HECTOR (see 3557), sailed to Delagoa Bay, where in July 1757 the NAARSTIGHEID, returning from Bengal, had been given up and set on fire (see 7502). During their stay at Delagoa Bay (16-06 till 06-09-1759) the SCHOLTENBURG and the HECTOR took aboard the cargo of the previous NAARSTIGHEID. On 28-09-1759 both ships were back at the Cape. There some members of the crews were accused of having smuggled with goods from the NAARSTIGHEID. After a protracted judicial inquiry the SCHOLTENBURG sailed for patria again in February 1760 (see ).

The ERFPRINS did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. 3757/7606 Is the third voyage of this ship, which during both preceding voyages was called DELFT (see 3696/7518); the new ERFPRINS replaced the previous ERFPRINS, wrecked in October 1758 near Calais (see 3739).

The MARlËNBOS initially sailed out on 22-01-1759, but five days later it ran aground at the 'Southern Haaks'; on 30-01 the ship returned to Texel. From 16 till 26-12-1759 the MARlËNBOS was at S. Tiago, where 5 seafarers and 7 soldiers deserted. The 2 passengers who embarked at the Cape were a Chinese married couple, released from exile. See also 3771. 3769 /- Is the fifth voyage of this ship, which during its four preceding voyages was called LEKKERLAND (see 3655/7525). On 27-03-1762 the ship was wrecked in a heavy storm near Ceylon.
On 27-03-1762 the SPARENDIJK was wrecked in a heavy storm near Ceylon.
In 1762 the GETROUWIGHEID ran aground in the Bay of Goa and was wrecked.
The MEERMIN remained on service of the authorities at the Cape until 09-04-1766, when it ran aground and was wrecked.
On 27-03-1762 the RHOON was wrecked in a heavy storm near Ceylon.

From 18 till 21-06 the VOORLAND was aground at the Flemish Banks; it lost its rudder. The ship called at Portsmouth (24-06 till 28-08) and at S. Tiago (04 till 07-10-1761); between Texel and Portsmouth 6 seafarers had already been pressed by an English ship in the open sea; at Portsmouth 3 seafarers were pressed, 11 seafarers and 6 soldiers deserted, one seafarer and 3 soldiers died, and one seafarer went to an other ship; at S. Tiago one seafarer deserted.
In 1764 the AMSTELWEERT got lost during a voyage to Surat.

The OOSTERBEEK called at Duins (17 till 22-12) and at Spithead (29-12-1761 till 23-01-1762); at Spithead the ship took over 23 seafarers from the ASCHAT (see 3825). Before sailing to Bengal it first called at Ceylon. See also 3834. In 1765 the OOSTERBEEK ran aground at East Java and was wrecked.

The AMSTELVEEN called at S. Vincente (07 till 15-06) and at Porto Prayo on S. Tiago (17 till 25-06-1762); at S. Vincente one seafarer deserted. The 22 persons who went ashore at the Cape included two seafarers and one soldier who deserted. On 05-08-1763 the AMSTELVEEN was wrecked off the Arabian Coast.
In 1766 the GIESSENBURG, sailing to Banda, was wrecked.

At the Cape one seafarer died. One day after the departure of the VROUWE PETRONELLA from the Cape 2 stowaways were discovered; they turned out to be English seafarers. During a voyage to Bengal the VROUWE PETRONELLA was wrecked at the Ganges, 11-01-1768.

The ZONNESTEIN remained on service in the inter-asiatic trade, carrying rice between Batavia and the Cape. During one of such voyages, sailing from the Cape to Batavia, the transport-ship was wrecked, January 1768.
See the LUXEMBURG (3959). In 1768 the VREDENHOF, sailing to Japan, was wrecked.

See the JONKVROUWE KORNELIA JAKOBA (4024). The VREEBURG replaced the VROUWE ELISABETH DOROTHEA, wrecked off Petten during a return voyage to Amsterdam, November 1767 (see 7738). The following data refer to the crew of the VREEBURG as well as to the crews of the GANZENHOEF (see 4031), the OUDERAMSTEL (4032), the HUIS TE BIJWEG (4034), the PALLAS (4035), and the COMPAGNIES WELVAREN (4036): 1318 seafarers, 706 soldiers, 76 craftsmen, and 6 passengers departed from the Republic or embarked at the Cape; 1077 seafarers, 437 soldiers, 60 craftsmen, and 4 passengers arrived at Batavia.
See the JONKVROUWE KORNELIA JAKOBA (4024) and the VREEBURG (4030). In 1770 the GANZENHOEF was wrecked during a voyage from Japan to Batavia.

See the LEKKERLUST (4046). In 1771 the LYCOCHTON was struck by lightning and burnt. The following data refer to the crew of the LYCOCHTON as well as to the crews of the WELGELEGEN (see 4049) and the BLEISWIJK (4051): 476 seafarers, 210 soldiers, 29 craftsmen, and 4 passengers departed from the Republic or embarked at the Cape; 413 seafarers, 172 soldiers, 20 craftsmen, and 4 passengers arrived at Batavia.
On 09-01-1772 the SCHOLTENBURG, sailing to Ceylon, was wrecked. See the VROUWE ANTHOINETTA KOENRARDINA (4054) and the ALKEMADE (4056).
On 27-01-1770 the LEIMUIDEN ran aground off the island Boavista, one of the Cape Verde Islands, and was wrecked.
On 12/13-01-1770 the WALENBURG ran ashore off Portsal at the coast of Bretagne (Brittany) and was wrecked. See 4090.

Specified data concerning the crew of the WALCHEREN: 264 seafarers, 74 soldiers, 14 craftsmen, and 2 passengers departed from Rammekens or embarked at the Cape. See also the SCHOONZICHT (4076). In 1773 the WALCHEREN was wrecked in the roadstead of Surat.

During the voyage 2 members of the crew deserted. The VROUWE  GEERTRUIDA  replaced  the WALENBURG, which, during a voyage to the Indies, was wrecked at the coast of Bretagne (Brittany), January 1770 (4072). See the HUIS OM (4084).

According to a letter sent from the Cape the GEINWENS departed from Texel with 350 persons aboard. At the departure from the Cape the crew consisted of 211 men. In 1776 GEINWENS was wrecked off Punto Gale.
From 22-10 till 15-11-1772 the JONGE THOMAS called at Duins. In the Table Bay at the Cape the ship was wrecked, 01-06-1773.
The BLEISWIJK called at Rochefort, 14-12-1772 till 14-01-1773. During the voyage 46 members of the crew deserted. In 1777 the BLEISWIJK was wrecked in the Indies.
Sailing on the Ganges the 'S LANDS WELVAREN ran aground, 28-08-1773. The ship was laid up in Bengal, 12-01-1774.
The ASCHAT sailed via Bantam, where 6 seafarers went ashore. During the voyage 3 members of the crew deserted. See also the INDIAAN (4210). In 1776 the ASCHAT was wrecked in the Indies.
See the MORGENSTER (4291). In 1783 the FOREEST was burnt in the Indies.
See the MORGENSTER (4291). In 1780 the DELFSHAVEN was wrecked in the Indies.

The EUROPA called at Portsmouth: 10 seafarers, 3 soldiers, and one craftsman died, one soldier was pressed by the English. See the PALLAS (4318). On 23-07-1784 the EUROPA, sailing off Indramajoe, was wrecked on a rock.
See the PALLAS (4318). In 1783 the VROUWE JOHANNA MARGARETHA was wrecked in the Indies.

See the OVERDUIN (4344). 4345/- Is the second voyage of this ship, which during its first voyage (4202/7992) was called WAKKERHEID. In 1783 or early in 1784 the COMPAGNIES WELV AREN, sailing from Batavia to Ceylon, was wrecked.
See the OVERDUIN (4344). On 12-09-1780 the JONGE HELLINGMAN ran aground at sand-banks off Bengal and was wrecked.
See the OVERDUIN (4344). On 04-1-1783 the BOTLAND was wrecked in the roads of Colombo.
In 1786 the PATRIOT was wrecked off Madurai in Southern India. See the OVERDUIN (4344).
Sailing to the Cape the JUNO was wrecked.
In 1788 the ship was wrecked in the Indies.
In 1783 the HERSTELDER was wrecked in the Indies.
The KATWIJK AAN DEN RIJN was bound for the Cape. On 07-10-1786 the ship ran aground in Simon's Bay; the Company's authorities at the Cape then decided to have it broken up.
The HELD WOLTEMADE was bound for Ceylon. On 01-07-1781, however, the ship was taken by two English frigates, which forced it to sail to Plymouth (arrival: 03-02-1782).
The VROUWE KATHARINA WILHELMINA was bound for China. Soon after its departure from Goeree, however, it was seized by the English off Bevesier; in January, 1781, the ship arrived at Duins.

The OOSTEREEM flew the Prussian flag. The ship was bound for China; on 21-01-1783, however, it ran aground at Goodwin's Sand and was wrecked. 4406/- Is the second voyage of this ship, which during the preceding voyage (4184/8014) was called VENUS.

In 1785 the VROUWE EVERHARDINA was wrecked during a voyage to Japan. The following data refer to the VROUWE EVERHARDINA as well as to the GOUVERNEUR-GENERAAL DE CLERCK (4430) and the VREDE (4442): 559 seafarers, 212 soldiers, and 14 craftsmen departed from Rammek-ens; 438 seafarers, 201 soldiers, and 9 passengers arrived at Batavia.
The ZEEDUIN sailed via Mauritius. In 1785, when sailing from Batavia to the Cape, the ship was wrecked. See the HOOLWERF (4419).
In 1789 the LAM was wrecked in the Indies.
In 1788 the MIDDELWIJK, sailing from Batavia to China, was wrecked.

During a heavy storm the PAREL lost its foremast and bowsprit. For that reason the ship was forced to call at S. Tiago, 30-01 till 30-03-1785. Two spars were  supplied by the PHOENIX, a Dutch man-of-war, which called at the island from 03 till 07-02-1785.
One day after its departure from Texel the NEERLANDS VRIJHEID ran aground off the coast of England and was wrecked.
The GANGES was bound for China. On 02-02-1786 the ship ran aground at Padstow in Cornwall and was wrecked.

The TRITON sailed via Santa Cruz on Tenerife. There it was loaded with the cargo of the outward-bound OUD HAARLEM (4495), which had departed from Texel in October, 1785, and was to return to Rammekens. The master of the OUD HAARLEM, Johan Bakker, probably changed ships, for in K.A. 4298, a source from the Cape, he is indicated as master of the TRITON. The latter ship left Santa Cruz on 04-08-1786. According to K.A. 4298 the crew consisted of 295 men; part of them may have embarked at Santa Cruz. At the departure from the Cape the TRITON was accompanied by a Dutch man-of-war. In 1792 the ship was wrecked in the Indies. The following data refer to the TRITON as well as to the JONGE FRANK (4521), the JUFFROUW JOHANNA (4540), the BARBESTEIN (4544), and the SURSEANCE (4557): 494 seafarers, 432 soldiers, 30 craftsmen, and 1 passenger departed from Rammekens; 495 seafarers, 248 soldiers, 19 craftsmen, and 5 passengers arrived at Batavia. and 5 passengers arrived at Batavia.

On 02-11-1786 the MERENBERG ran aground off Crookhaven in Ireland. Its cargo was taken over by the outward-bound MERENBERG (4556), previously called EIKENWOUD, which departed from Texel in March, 1787. The stranded MERENBERG was broken up in 1787.

The MERENBERG sailed via Crookhaven in Ireland in order to take over the cargo of the other MERENBERG, ran aground there in November, 1786 (4535). 4556/8223 Is the second voyage of this ship, which during its preceding voyage (4452/8159) was called EIKENWOUD. The following data refer to both the MERENBERG and the BELVLIET (4563): 269 seafarers, 135 soldiers, 16 craftsmen, and 3 passengers departed from Texel; 226 seafarers, 94 soldiers, 8 craftsmen, and 1 passenger arrived at Batavia.
According to K.A. 4304 the departing crew consisted of 229 men. In 1789 the BELVLIET was wrecked in the Indies. See the MERENBERG (4556).
At the Cape the JONGE FRANK took over part of the cargo of the homeward-bound MARIA, wrecked there in August, 1788 (8207). Being at anchor in the roads of Batavia the JONGE FRANK sank.

According to K.A. 4390a the departing crew consisted of 364 men. Soon after having sailed from Rammekens the ZUIDERBURG lost its rudder; for that reason the ship had to call at Plymouth, 12-01 till 02-03-1789.
In July the OOSTZAANDAM, sailing to the Cape, lost its foremast.
The STERRESCHANS was bound for the Cape. On 20-05-1793 the ship ran aground at the Cape and was wrecked.
On 01-12-1789 the CANTON departed from Goeree; five days later it arrived at Texel. Continuing its voyage from Batavia to China the CANTON was wrecked in the South China Sea.
In 1793 the BATAVIER ran aground and was wrecked in the Indies
Originally the INDUS departed on 27-08-1790; it had to return to Texel, however. From 10 till 24-09-1790 the ship was at Duins. In 1794 the INDUS was burnt down in the roads of Batavia.
In 1793 the WILLEM DE VIERDE was taken by the French in Sunda Strait.
From 17-10-1790 till 21-02-1791 the VALK was at Glückstadt. On 27-02- 1791 the ship was wrecked at the banks off Yarmouth.
The NEGOTIE was bound for Ceylon. On 26 and 27-11-1790, however, the ship was wrecked and went to pieces off Texel.
During the voyage the CONSTITUTIE lost all its topmasts. See the CHRISTOFFEL COLUMBUS (4688).
The ZAANSTROOM was bound for the Cape. On 28-02-1791, however, the ship ran aground off Barfleur in France. See the CHRISTOFFEL COLUMBUS (4688).
According to K.A. 4336 A. Hansonmaat was master. In 1 796 the DRAAK, being at anchor in the roads of Batavia, was struck by lightning and burnt down.

On 04-08-1793 the Company's authorities sent the ship to the Delagoa River in order to look for the homeward-bound DEMERARY (8363), which had departed from Batavia in February, 1793, and was missing since. Eventually the STAR was taken by the English.

The 24 passengers indicated in the first column included 23 Chinese; 20 of them arrived at Batavia. In 1795 the CONSTANTIA was at anchor at the roads of Malacca; there it was taken by the English, when they captured the city.

The 44 passengers indicated in the first column included 39 Chinese; 37 of them arrived at Batavia. After having called at Batavia the HERTOG VAN BRUNSWIJK possibly sailed on to China. In 1795 or 1796 the ship was wrecked off Batavia.
On 25-03-1794 the FAAM was taken by the French and brought to Brest.

On 23-04-1794 the VROUWE MARIA GEERTRUIDA sailed from Rammekens to Texel. Twenty days after its final departure from Texel the ship was seized by the French; later that year it was recaptured by the English and taken to Plymouth, where it arrived on 09-06-1794.
The CASTOR was bound for the Cape. Eventually the ship was taken by the English.
On 23-06-1794 the EENSGEZINDHEID sailed from Rammekens to Texel. On 15-02-1796 the ship was seized by the English at Ceylon.
On 22-05-1794 the MARIA LOUISA sailed from Goeree to Texel. On 21-10-1795 the ship was captured by the English off the Cape and taken to the Cape.
From 09 till 11-09-1794 the KRAAI was at Portsmouth. The dates concerning the call at the Cape are unknown. The KRAAI kept on sailing in the Indies for at least five years; eventually it was wrecked.
In August 1795, the GEERTRUIDA was captured by the English at the Cape.
The WESTERMEER was bound for Batavia. Four days after the departure from Texel, however, the ship was seized by the French.
The WILLEMSTAD EN BOETSELAAR was bound  for Batavia. In August 1795, the ship was captured by the English at the Cape.
The ZORG called at Plymouth, 26-12-1794 till 04-11-1795. Three days after the departure from Plymouth the ship ran aground off Boulogne and was wrecked.

Return fleet (5001-5003) under command of oppercommies Kornelis de Houtman aboard the MAURITIUS. Total number of those on board 90. One of them died on the return voyage. April 26th. the HOLLANDIA lost the others out of sight, but May 26th. they met again at St. Helena.
Return fleet (5039-5041), under command of admiral W. Harmensz. and vice-admiral H. Brouwer which lost sight of the DUIFJE off Cape Agulhas. The DUIFJE sailed separately to Zeeland.
From Bantam to Patani to take over the cargo of a Portuguese prize-ship, and lost on the coast of Guinea.
Ran ashore, sailing through the Amelander Gat and was lost.
Burnt in a fight with a Portuguese carrack off St. Helena, 13-06-1613; a part of the crew sailed back to Holland aboard the VLISSINGEN and the BANTAM (5098).
Return fleet (5105-5108) with Pieter Both aboard the BANDA; this ship foundered on a reef in a hurricane near Mauritius; 30 deaths, including Pieter Both, 06-03-1615.
Ran ashore in a hurricane near Mauritius and was lost, 06-03-1615.
Foundered on a reef near Mauritius during a hurricane, 06-03-1615; 30 deaths.
Lost in a storm near Madagascar, 18-03-1625.
The master died before arrival at the Cape; via Mascarenes, arrival 01-04-1625 and from 10-04 till 25-10 in the Bay of Antongil; fougth 2 Portuguese carracks near St. Helena, afterwards lost.
Burnt on 20-04 or 30-04 at 4°33' North.
Lost off Texel.
Lost near the Borkumer Rif, August 1632.
Ran ashore in the Sunda Strait, off Varkenseiland, 02-01-1637. Part of the cargo was lost, crew saved and ship broken up.
Wrecked off Texel.

Second return fleet (5346-5348) under command of vice-commandeur Reinier van 't Zuim aboard the WITTE OLIFANT. The HAARLEM was wrecked 25-03-1647 in Table Bay, between Robben Island and the mainland. The fleet sailed via St. Helena.
Captured from the English.
The AVONDSTER returned to Batavia because of leakage (28-02-1657). Part of the cargo was taken over by the PAREL. It stayed in the Indies and was wrecked in the Bay of Gale (Ceylon) (02-07-1659).

The master died and was succeeded by Pieter Gerritsz. Second return fleet (5469-5470) under command of Van Twist aboard the NAARDEN. Both ships lost each other out of sight, 29/30-03-1659. The ERASMUS sailed via the Comoro Islands and Madagascar because of damage. At the Cape it waited for the return fleet of 18-12-1659. The ship called at St. Helena. The crew included 16 Portuguese prisoners.

First return fleet (5491-5497) under command of Arnold de Vlaming van Oudshoorn(t) aboard the WAPEN VAN HOLLAND and Jakob Willemsz. (vice-comm. @+@ ). At the Cape the fleet waited for the return fleet of 30-01-1662. Johan van der Laan became the new commander. The ARNHEM was wrecked at Brandao, an island east of Madagascar (12-02-1662); about 80 survivors reached Mauritius and were picked up later.
Was wrecked in the Indian Ocean during a storm at 25/26° S. (10-02-1662).
Was wrecked in the Indian Ocean during a storm at 25/26° S (10/11-02-1662).
Was wrecked in the Indian Ocean during a storm at 25/26° S. (10/11-02-1662).
Second return fleet (5498-5499) under command of Zacharias Wagenaar. After the Cape under command of Johan van der Laan (see above). The ANJELIER was wrecked at Terschelling(?).
Aboard the MAARSSEVEEN was Adriaan van der Meide, vice-commandeur of the return fleet. The ship was wrecked in the battle of Lowestoft against the English, 13-06-1665.
The NAGELBOOM was hired by the Admiralties to fight the English; it was taken by the English on 13-06-1665.
Aboard the ORANJE was Dirk Steur, commandeur of the return fleet. The ship was hired by the Admiralties to fight the English; it was burnt in the battle of Lowestoft, 13-06-1665.
Was hired by the Admiralties to fight the English; taken by the English on 19-09-1665.

First return fleet (5523-5533) under command of Pieter de Bitter aboard the WALCHEREN (5532) and Jakob Burkhorst aboard the PHOENIX (5530). At the Cape the KOGGE and the NIEUWENHOVE (5534 and 5535) joined the fleet. The combined fleet sailed via Bergen (Norway) because of the war; 12-08-1665: battle in the Bay of Bergen against an English fleet (25 men killed and 70 wounded). After the departure from Bergen two ships were taken by the English (see below). The AMSTELLAND returned to Bergen on 16-09-1665; departure: in October. On 25-10-1665 the ship was wrecked east of Terschelling; its cargo was mainly saved.
Was wrecked in a storm near the Cape (Febr. 1665).
Aboard the PHOENIX was Jakob Burkhorst, vice-commandeur of the return fleet. The ship sailed via Bergen (call: 08-08 till 02-09-1665); on 13-09-1665 it was taken by the English at Dogger Bank.

Separate fleet (5536-5537) from Bengal via Ceylon (departure on 29-12-1665) and Malabar; joined the fleet of 30-01-1666 at the Cape. The original cargo of the KALF from Bengal had an invoice value of 190,754. The ship sailed via Bergen. It was wrecked in the Vlie, 22 men were saved.
Original cargo from Bengal: 364,044. The VENENBURG was taken by the English.
On 19-09-1667 the WAPEN VAN AMSTERDAM was wrecked south of Iceland; 14 men were saved.
Was wrecked near the Faeroe Is. in September 1667. Many men were drowned.

Return fleet (5642-5647) under command of Abraham Huibrechtsen aboard the WAPEN VAN VEERE (5647) and Eduard Goudsmit aboard the PIJNACKER (5645). The ALPHEN was taken by the English at St. Helena, May 1673.

The EUROPA originally was a French ship, captured in the Indies (October 1672). According to Daghregister 1673/4 the ship left the Cape on 10-05-1673. At St. Helena it was taken by the English, May 1673.
Due to wrong instructions the PAPENBURG was taken by the English off Texel, August 1673.
Aboard the WAPEN VAN VEERE was Abraham Huibrechtsen, commandeur of the return fleet. The ship was taken by the English at St. Helena, May 1673.

Immediately after passing through Sunda Strait the ship lost sight of the fleet. Due to a French attack it did not call at the Cape, and sailed via Pernambuco (Brazil). Aboard the VRIJE ZEE was Jakob Ganswijk, schout-bij-nacht of the return fleet.
Captured from the English.
The AZIË was wrecked on 17° N.
Aboard the TIDORE was Hendrik van Oudshoorn, commandeur of the return fleet. On 27-09-1683 the ship was wrecked at Ameland.

Second return fleet (5782-5788) under command of Jorephas Vos aboard the RIDDERSCHAP VAN HOLLAND (5787). According to Valentijn the fleet departed on 16-02-1684. Acc. to K.A. 1271 the fleet had a crew of 1022 men, among whom 133 soldiers and 53 impotenten. During a heavy storm in the Indian Ocean the AFRIKA was wrecked, 23-04-1684.
Acc. to Valentijn the ship departed on 06-12-1685 from Bengal. On 16-02-1686 it was wrecked at Terra de Natal.
In 1690 burned down at Amsterdam.

First return fleet (5865-5872) under command of Johan Parve aboard the NEDERLAND (5866) and Abraham Post aboard the LAND VAN SCHOUWEN (5870). At the Cape the first fleet of 07-02-1690 (except the CHINA, 5874) and the second of 12-03-1690 from Ceylon joined the fleet. The KAPELLE was wrecked near the Shetland Islands.
The PIJLSWAART was wrecked near the Shetland Islands.
Aboard the LAND VAN SCHOUWEN was Abraham Post, vice-commandeur of the return fleet. The ship went astray from the fleet at 62°N. and was wrecked near the Shetland Islands.
The first ships from Ceylon (5873-5875) joined the first return fleet of 29-12-1689 at the Cape. The WAPEN VAN ALKMAAR was wrecked near the Shetland Islands.

Willem Kemp was commandeur of the return fleet. Acc. to K.A. 4007 the crew consisted of 184 men. The WATERLAND sailed via Saldanha Bay (01 till 21-05-1692). On 12-09-1692 the ship was attacked by the French and sunk with all hands at 45°N.

The ship from Ceylon (5900-5903) joined the return fleet of 30-01-1692 at the Cape. The GOEDE HOOP was wrecked at the Cape, 05-06-1692; from the cargo 562,488 was saved and carried to patria aboard the EMMENES (5911).
On 10-06-1692 the HOGERGEEST was wrecked at the Cape.
According to K.A . 1475 the ROSKAM was taken by the French, successively by the English, and finally restored to the Company.

The BANTAM was wrecked off Vlissingen, 03-12-1697. Aboard the BANTAM was Hendrik Pronk, commandeur of the return fleet (5962-5973); he died during the voyage and was buried at the Cape. Schout-by-nacht Hendrik Gravia aboard the DRIEBERGEN (5964) replaced him. Hendrik van Buitenhem was vice-commandeur aboard the STAD KEULEN (5967).
The WADDINXVEEN was wrecked at the Cape, 24-05-1697; 4 men were saved.
The OOSTERLAND was wrecked in the Table Bay, 24-05-1697.
The NOORDGOUW carried the cargoes of the WADDINXVEEN and the OOSTERLAND, both wrecked at the Cape (see 5973 and 5975).
Wrecked on 29-05-1700 off Pernambuco.
The HAZELNOOT sunk in the Spanish Sea.
Lost near Mauritius.
Lost near Mauritius.
The BENNEBROEK was wrecked in Struys Baai, east of Cape Agulhas.
Lost after departure.
Lost after departure.
Wrecked at Mauritius.
Wrecked in 1722 between Batavia and the Cape.
According to N.A. 1902 XXVI, 94 the cargo was 357,691. Wrecked in 1722 near Mauritius.
Wrecked in 1722 near Mauritius.
Wrecked on 08-01-1722 at 26°15' S.
Wrecked on 08-01-1722 at 26°15'S.
Wrecked in 1722 near Mauritius.
Wrecked near Cape Agulhas
Lost at 31°S.
Lost at 31°S. According to N.A. 1902 XXVI, 94 the THEODORA departed on 11-12-1725 from Batavia.
Lost at 31°S.
Wrecked on its way to patria.
Wrecked at Terschelling on 28-09-1732
Wrecked between Batavia and the Cape.

Wrecked at the Cape on 21-05-1737. The total loss of those on board the ships, wrecked on 21-05-1737, was 208; the loss of cargo amounted up to f 1,921,532 (see also: 6992, 6993, 6998-7000, 7002, and 7003.)
Wrecked at the Cape on 21-05-1737.
Wrecked at the Cape on 21-05-1737.
Wrecked at the Cape on 21-05-1737.
Wrecked at the Cape on 21-05-1737.
Wrecked at the Cape on 21-05-1737.
Wrecked at the Cape on 21-05-1737.
Wrecked at the Cape on 21-05-1737.
The 91 men aboard the RE1GERSBROEK included 71 seafarers. The ship was wrecked off Zeeland and smashed against the Westkapelsedijk.
Wrecked in the Channel between Goudstaart and Dartmouth on 08-1 1-1738.
Lost sight of by the accompanying ships since 17-02-1739. Wrecked between Bengal and the Cape.
Lost between Ceylon and the Cape.
Lost between Ceylon and the Cape.
Wrecked between Batavia and the Cape. Commandeur of the return fleet was Jurriaan Wolbergen, master of the KASTEEL VAN TILBURG (7088).
Wrecked between Batavia and the Cape.
Wrecked between Batavia and the Cape.
Jurriaan Wolbergen was commandeur of the return fleet. The KASTEEL VAN TILBURG was wrecked between Batavia and the Cape.
Wrecked between Batavia and the Cape.
Lost between Batavia and the Cape.

The 22 passengers aboard the AMSTERDAM included admiraal Adriaan Valkenier with 5 servants and 13 lijfschutten (bodyguards). At the Cape this former Gouverneur-Generaal was arrested; he was accused by the future G.-G. Van Imhoff of being responsible for the notorious 'Chinese Murders' in Batavia in 1740. In August, 1742, Valkenier was transported back to Batavia (see 3241). The AMSTERDAM was wrecked off the Shetland Islands.
On 27-05-1742 the ENKHUIZEN arrived at Robben Island. Lost between the Cape and Patria. See also 3274.
The 116 man aboard the ABBEKERK included 16 impotenten and 6 passengers. The ship was wrecked between the Cape and Patria. See also 3313.
Wrecked between the Cape and Patria, 19-05-1744.
Wrecked between the Cape and Patria, 19-05-1744.

The OPLETTENDHEID did not call at the Cape but at False Bay. Originally the OPLETTENDHEID was a French ship, called JASON; it was captured by the English (05-02-1745), brought to Batavia (13-02), and sold to the Dutch (16-02).
As the OPLETTENDHEID (7226) the TOEVALLIGHEID originally was a French ship, called HERCULES; it was captured by the English (05-02-1745), brought to Batavia (13-02), and sold to the Dutch (16-02).
The ship was wrecked off Guinea.

The 8 passengers were condemned persons. In February, 1751, the WAPEN VAN HOORN lost all its masts in a storm; a few days later is was spoken by the OVERNES (7348) east of Cape Agulhas (27-02). The WAPEN VAN HOORN called at the island Ascension, 10-05-1751. On 28-01-1752 the ship sank off Cape Finisterre; Jakob Greef and 32 other members of the crew were saved.

Crew at the Cape: 92. On 22-05-1752 the DIEMEN was spoken by the STRALEN (sailing to Batavia, see 3558), in the Channel: the ship appeared to have lost its mainmast. After the arrival of the ship at patria its name was altered into KASTEEL VAN TILBURG (see its last two voyages, 3580/7475 and 3706/-).
Wrecked on 10-01-1752 on Geldria's Doogte, wreck discovered.
Sailing off Bengal the Hartekamp ran aground in a heavy storm and was wrecked.
Sailing off Bengal the WITSBURG ran aground in a heavy storm and was wrecked.

In December 1754, after calling at Batavia, the BAARZANDE ran on a rock and was severely damaged; on 18-12 the ship reached Bantam, where it remained for almost three months to be repaired. Another ship, the JAGER, from now on called BAARZANDE, took over its cargo (value: 360,827) and carried it to patria (see 7453). In 1756 the previous BAARZANDE, since March 1755 called JAGER, finally returned to Rammekens (see 7468).
The 10 passengers included nine condemned persons, eight criminals disembarked at the Cape. Crew at the Cape: 119. The NIEUWVIJVERVREUGD exploded and was wrecked off Shetland Islands.

The NAARSTIGHEID departed from Bengal twelve days late (see 7498 and 7499). In June 1757 the ship reached Delagoa Bay in a very tumbledown conditon; on 01-07-1757 the NAARSTIGHEID was finally given up and set on fire. Its cargo was transported to the Cape by the HECTOR (see 3557), which sailed twice from the Cape to the Bay, and by the SCHOLTENBURG, which had arrived at the Cape in March 1 759 (see 3743). The SCHOLTENBURG finally carried the cargo from the Cape to patria in 1760 (see 7581).
Twelve days after the arrival at Texel the SPANDERSWOUD caught fire and burnt completely, 23-12-1757.

The four passengers included two condemned persons; they disembarked at the Cape. After the arrival of the ship at patria its name was altered into ERFPRINS (see 3757/7607, etc.); the new ERFPRINS replaced the previous ERFPRINS, stranded and wrecked off Calais, October 1758 (see 3739).
The three passengers included one condemned person. After having been unloaded the BUITENZORG was wrecked off Texel.
The SCHOLTENBURG carried the cargo of the NAARSTIGHEID, given up and set on fire in Delagao Bay, July 1757 (see 7502). See also the outward voyage of the SCHOLTENBURG, .
